items.synopsis: ASIC has ordered buy now, pay later provider Humm to stop signing new customers under an interim order, while a deal to increase the US debt ceiling edges closer. Follow live

title.children: Buy now, pay later provider Humm barred from signing new customers, US debt ceiling deal edges closer, ASX opens lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened slightly lower on Friday morning, down 0.1% as of 10:30am AEST, sitting at 7,143 points. Fisher & Paykel has suffered the biggest loss so far, after the company disclosed its profit and revenue has fallen for the 2023 Financial Year, but the company says it's "on track" to return to more normal conditions after COVID-19. That's also resulted in a big dip in the healthcare sector, which is down 0.5%. As for other sectors, only utilities and basic materials are in positive territory (and even then, they're only just in the green), while all others are in the red. The top five companies gaining ground so far are: BrainChip +3.7% Liontown Resources +1.9% Incitec Pivot +1.4% Fortescue Metals +1.2% Domino's Pizza +0.8% And the companies who have suffered the biggest losses: Fisher & Paykel Healthcare -5% CSR -4.9% Allkem -2% Lifestyle Communities -1.7% Mirvac -1.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as Fisher & Paykel's profit and revenue falls

children.content: The Australian share market has opened slightly lower on Friday morning, down 0.1% as of 10:30am AEST, sitting at 7,143 points.
Fisher

Paykel has suffered the biggest loss so far, after the company disclosed its profit and revenue has fallen for the 2023 Financial Year, but the company says it's "on track" to return to more normal conditions after COVID-19.
That's also resulted in a big dip in the healthcare sector, which is down 0.5%.
As for other sectors, only utilities and basic materials are in positive territory (and even then, they're only just in the green), while all others are in the red.
The top five companies gaining ground so far are:
BrainChip +3.7%
Liontown Resources +1.9%
Incitec Pivot +1.4%
Fortescue Metals +1.2%
Domino's Pizza +0.8%
And the companies who have suffered the biggest losses:
Fisher
Paykel Healthcare -5%
Allkem -2%
Lifestyle Communities -1.7%
Mirvac -1.3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's been a big week for buy now, pay later services â now the financial watchdog ASIC has ordered Humm to stop providing its products to new customers under an interim order. In a statement shared on the ASX, Humm Group confirmed it has received an interim stop order from ASIC "in relation to concerns regarding the target market determination for the Humm buy now payer later product". Humm says it's complying with ASIC's request, but can continue to offer its services to existing customers. "Hummgroup is seeking to work closely with ASIC to urgently address the concerns raised in relation to the Humm BNPL target market determination," the statement said. Humm's CEO Rebecca James quit the company earlier this month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Buy now, pay later service Humm to stop issuing products to new customers

children.content: It's been a big week for buy now, pay later services â now the financial watchdog ASIC has ordered
Humm to stop providing its products to new customers
under an interim order.

In a statement shared on the ASX, Humm Group confirmed it has received an interim stop order from ASIC "in relation to concerns regarding the target market determination for the Humm buy now payer later product".
Humm says it's complying with ASIC's request, but can continue to offer its services to existing customers.
"Hummgroup is seeking to work closely with ASIC to urgently address the concerns raised in relation to the Humm BNPL target market determination," the statement said.
Humm's CEO Rebecca James quit the company earlier this month.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Data out from Germany overnight shows the country's economy has slipped into a recession, after household spending dipped due to the pressures of high inflation. Gross domestic product in Germany fell by 0.3% in the first three months of the year, and followed a decline of 0.5% in the final three months of last year. An economy is defined as being in recession after two successive negative quarters of economic growth. Germany's finance minister Christian Lindner said the GDP data showed "surprisingly negative signals". The country's economy minister Robert Habeck said Germany's previous high dependency on Russia for energy supply led to the recession, and growth forecasts were much bleaker. Household consumption was down 1.2% quarter on quarter after price, seasonal and calendar adjustments. Government spending also decreased significantly, by 4.9%, on the quarter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Germany enters recession as inflation deters household spending

led to the recession, and growth forecasts were much bleaker.
Household consumption was down 1.2% quarter on quarter after price, seasonal and calendar adjustments. Government spending also decreased significantly, by 4.9%, on the quarter.
